summary: In an England of the future, Alex (Malcolm McDowell) and his "Droogs" spend their nights getting high at the Korova Milkbar before embarking on "a little of the old ultraviolence," while jauntily warbling "Singin' in the Rain." After he's jailed for bludgeoning the Cat Lady to death, Alex submits to behavior modification technique to earn his freedom; he's conditioned to abhor violence. Returned to the world defenseless, Alex becomes the victim of his prior victims.

reviews.content: This movie faced a lot of criticism and controversy upon its release, and despite the controversy never stopping, it seems more appreciated today. However, I understand both points of view. On the one hand, A Clockwork Orange is very garish, strident, and bawdy whether with its story, script, or filming. But on the other hand, it has a unique plot, great performances, and magnificent camerawork from Stanley Kubrick (which is generally expected from him). This movie is not made for kicking back and relaxing, and one needs to be in a specific mood.

Esse filme mostra o tão quão podre a sociedade pode ser, e tão violenta e como estamos abandonados perto de monstros assassinos e estupradores. Meu ódio por bandido veio desse filme.  Nem venham me dizer que sou aquilo, pois não sou.
Stanley Kubrick's finest and an absolute must watch for any film fan.
It's my favorite Kubrick. Deep, theatrical and of incredible sound.
Best movie it's slightly disturbing and very sad BUT VERY GOOD also a classic

What to make of this movie; one of Kubrick's kids. That's pretty much it. It's just one of Kubrick's kids. It's too ironic to really be about anything. Like Joker's helmet in Full Metal Jacket; Peace sign: Born to kill. I think Alex in this movie is born to kill. And he enjoys it. I'm not sure if Kubrick thinks this is problematic. What he does find problematic is Alex's so called rehabilitation. Why? Because it is wrong to take away a humans ability to choose between right and wrong. But what about the way Alex was living his life; part of a gang; hurting innocent people? I'm afraid the real edge to this movie is that it is so silent when it comes to that. In fact, the film seems to want us to sympathize with Alex when the tables are turned. Alex however is very charming; ultra charming; I think that's where this movie gets its lasting appeal. His charm seems to be rooted in a little of that ultra violence. I think in his way Stanley Kubrick was illustrating the kind of person who becomes a dictator; and showing how such an individual could get away with doing hideous deeds.
Singing in the rain won't quite sound the same anymore, some good and innovative stuff going on but its maybe just too weird.

All my credits go to Malcolm McDowell as well as Director-Writer-Producer, Stanley Kubrick with the novelist, Anthony Burgess of A Clockwork Orange...

In actual fact, this is not my first time to watch this motion picture besides in a Theater in Wan Chai, Hong Kong many many years ago...
An absolute masterpiece eluding to our minds and rhoughts
Phenomenal movie! Wow!
it is a classic, but just not to my taste, allthough McDowell ready does deliver in this movie.

This cold, cynical film is tough to watch in parts, especially in today's climate, but there's a lot to think about here. Visually this film is wonderful, especially 50 years later. The whole 60s mod-futurist aesthetic at the same time is dystopian and terrifying.
It seems like the movie is in the Joker universe, and that's why I understand it and you should watch it
A dystopian nightmare that is still relevant today.

It is beautiful that not only you watch some movie that investigates an ethical problem, but you are constantly exposed to ethical dilemmas when it comes to what to feel about this character. Kubrick never surprises you and you always have a fine cinematic experience
amo com todas as minhas forças
Uma verdadeira obra prima

This is one of the most riveting, glorious films ever made. While not for the faint hearted, it is an amazing social commentary. The long, drawn out scenes of violence for the sake of violence is painful and uncomfortable, but necessary. For most of the scenes I was glued to my seat, eyes wide and unblinking, with absolute terror keeping me nailed down. I felt sick. But that is not a negative thing, it accomplished exactly what it was trying to. If you can handle intense violence and sexual content, then give it a try. It isn't made for people like Alex--although, it may seem like that to a few. This film is made to make you think, and make you consider moral goodness. It's meant to make you uncomfortable. Again, if you prefer light hearted films, then don't touch this, but it is a wonderful film.

"A Clockwork Orange" doesn't take it's time to build & goes for hitting you fast while relying on Malcolm McDowell's narration to fill you in. Dark & violent dystopian interwoven with a love of art while taking on criminal reform & how violence has knock on effect on society.

I had been on a Kubrick-spree when I first watched this, I had started to develop a theory that Kubrick was overrated. This film quickly put me in my place. This is a true work of art. Masterly stylistic is every way, every single shot resonates and speaks to you like a friend making a joke. This film is visually stimulating, rivetingly witty, and contains some of the best writing I have ever experienced. Yes, experienced. This was an experience, and an eye widening one at that.
I would rate this as one of the 10 best. It's a movie you can watch multiple times and still enjoy

After watching the first 20 minutes of this film I wondered if I would manage to get through the full thing. It seemed un-artistically degrading with scenes of sexual assault lingering longer than necessary. The second half I found more interesting as the narrative becomes quite thought-provoking and is more of a commentary on morals and society. One thing I admired about this film was the use of sound and music, I could see similarities to The Shining in that respect with Kubrick using sound in a disturbing and unconventional way to make a scene even more bizarre than it already is. And although the colours and cinematography are often pleasing to the eye I do not feel like I would ever watch again.

This is a movie that you should not watch as a kid but maybe now kids can watch it cuz they're so messed up from everything else but it's one of Malcolm McDowell's classic Movies and maybe read the book or maybe not it's just one of those messed up '70s movies that everybody watched or avoided
Riveting film, the only caveat is that a lot of the dialogue is incredibly hard to understand because it's in a made-up language
It was confusing and peculiar but somehow managed to pull it off with its strange charm.

With this film, a world heritage of cinema, Stanley Kubrick has reached a level of artistic mastery that would make Michelangelo pale in comparison. To make a film an art form, it must have the innovation of a Chaplin or Jean-Luc Godard. Furthermore, for a film to be a masterpiece, it must have music, direction, and great performances by the cast. Nevertheless, this film easily fulfills these requirements, and miraculously, it is a perfect work of art, with outstandingly high quality visual beauty far above the audience. For 136 minutes, one feels as if one has stepped into an exhibition of paintings or photographs that are sigh-inducingly vivid, beautiful, sometimes violent, and sometimes insane. The film's elaborate camerawork is erotic, but not vulgar, like a sensual film. The clarity of vision, both pictorial and photographic, is unparalleled. Any of the scenes, even the still ones, would make a grade-A photo book. Without a doubt, it is the best film made in the entire world in 1971. It deserves to be the "Pietà" of the film world.
I dont know if this is comedy drama or movie on acid eather way a its really good movie with awesome acting.
I have no idea how some of this is still legal but it's brilliance filmmaking.

I couldn't continue watching after minute 15, I know it's a cult movie and I should see it in full, but I couldn't stand it. 2 scenes of sexual abuse in just 15 minutes of the movie??? I'm so sorry, but I can't watch it, violence doesn't matter to me, but seeing sexual abuse without any kind of sensitivity makes my stomach hurt and makes me want to throw up. At this point I don't give a shit if the movie is one of the best in the world of cinema, I'm not going to watch it.

While not Kubrick's best--the nudity, violence, and sex smacks as gratuitous at times, some  exaggerated and daft acting, and the synopsis is a bit muddled (ambivalent, perhaps meant to be)--but is still worth a watch for the spectacle of the whole thing, as well as for McDowell's performance.

Spoilers: This has legs. I watched it half a century ago. And it holds up now on its own terms. I suppose good art always holds up. From Cain killing Abel to US mass murders this year, humans seem to can't get out of their own way. This is at once a sad observation about life, a satire on how people, governments try to deal with this penchant for destruction, maybe more superficial than intellectually honest, and a poke in the eye, as whether either free will and choice vs. drug or psychological control of people can work on civility without disrespecting the people. The imagery in this and gross illustration of sex and violence pull no punches. Kubrick wants us to feel it as much as see it. The overall warning is that no matter how hard it is to figure this out, we ought to do it, so that civility and common courtesy and common decency have a chance. To say Kubrick is not optimistic about us doing that may be right. But maybe the whole point of his art is to get us moving, not just appreciating the art. This was beyond groundbreaking, and probably has gotten people talking  for 50 years about interventions that can work without thwarting human nature yet minimizing abuse and destruction we so often visit upon one another.

this is my favourite movie, it's cinical, outstanding and confusing in some sort of way that makes so much sense, for no reason. The use of camera from Stanley Kubrick and screen play, are just imaculate, i love it.

I love this movie, it's raw, it's violent, it's dark and depressing, but it has a powerful message and one to take into account, its cinematography is excellent and what to say about the music and the performances, because of its themes it is more than obvious than not It is for everyone, but does that matter for it to be a watershed in the history of cinema?

A klassno and ochen interesno movie by the great Stanley Kubrick and an obvious must-see classic for the fans of the psychological thriller genre. The story, the soundtrack, and the actors all play out beautifully in a fever dream-England landscape. 

Overall, it is a great movie that leaves you thinking about the questions it asks and the answers they can have.

Um filme com que uma direção espetacular de Stanley Kubrick mostra a real face da ''psicopatia americana''. O protagonista da trama é um ser despresivel, asqueiroso e nojento, mas mesmo assim, sentimos sua dor ao perceber os conflitos internos que o mesmo sofre. Uma coisa a se destacar deste filme é sua trilha sonora composta por musicas naturalmente controversas para a proposta inicial, mas que ironicamente se encaixam perfeitamente com o tom ''engraçado'', mais para um engraçado melancólico mesmo, e também sua edição minimamente pensada a fazer com que os takes de camera proporcionem maior agonia e desconforto possivel, com reforço da direção de Kubrick. O filme é genial e realmente o faz questionar qual é o limite que a humanidade pode chegar, mas devidamente apressado a chegar no seu ponto principal, a prisão e a ditadura que parece ''justa'', mas é apenas cilada. Um ponto negativo a se destacar é a falta de desenvolvimento dos personagens que, mesmo que não mude muito no filme, seria algo a se aproveitar. Como por exemplo, os outros integrantes da gangue de Alex e os pais do mesmo, eles poderiam ser bem mais aprofundados em base nos conflitos que eles tem com o protagonista, mas fora isso, o filme é espetacular e um clássico.
9/10

One of the most important and interesting movies ever made, it never fails to shock! I love this film for its complete originality, there has not been to this day a more weird yet thought provoking film even 51 years later!

Oh, a Clockwork Orange. A movie I horribly misunderstood growing up. A graphic and violent take set in a futuristic society. Malcolm McDowell leads a gang of hoodlums in multiple crimes including rape, murder, theft and destruction. The ending always freaked me out with Alex hooked up to the machine, eyes wide open watching those surreal images. Wonderfully shot, another Kubrick class, just not my favorite of the bunch.
My favorit scene is, Alex going crazy, when he hears a Ludwig Van Beethoven.

It's a "sort" of masterpiece.  I'm frequently amazed at the "Kubrick-isms" I see in many of his movies.  I saw Clockwork Orange as a young 20-something pot smoker in the 90s.  At the time, I recall enjoying watching it.  Over the years, I forgot most of it, but upon rewatching I was again riveted by many aspects of its originality and creativity.  There's much about it that doesn't represent "real" human emotions, but it does ask some very interesting philosophical questions, especially about the nature of violence and appropriate punishment.  I really like the soundtrack even though many might think parts of it are woefully dated.  The casting is quite good and I always love hearing British English.  Some parts of the movie are downright disturbing and hard to stomach, but I still like the overall film as a work of art.  I enjoyed revisiting this.  I may watch again some day and the 5 bucks I paid to own it on iTunes is worth it.

[11/24/20]: Did Chekov's gun well. I like the philosophical underpinnings of free will and rehabilitation vs retribution; torturing/curing the humanity out of a vile person. Compelling main character despite him being so unlikeable. Certainly not boring. (Thom: Was it a message about a man with a choice (even if they are bad) is better than a man without a choice?). It's a movie that is thought-provoking and sparks conversation as much as it sparks a powerful emotional and even physical response as you witness the film itself.
One of the greatest I have seen. Wow!

Nadie sabe que es o que significa "A Clockwork Orange" (1971). En su mayoría parece una subversión inteligente de géneros como el drama, el terror, el humor negro y la ciencia ficción, pero con un toque de Stanley Kubrick que la hace una obra más particular que otras películas que de cierto modo son similares. Llena de diversión macabra y cambios de tono que funcionan, en parte gracias a la inquietante actuación de Malcolm McDowell, esta película es un salvaje y provocativo desfile de Kubrick que explora temas de traición, irrupción doméstica, las inevitables consecuencias del experimento humano, y el rencor de la sociedad, por decir algunos. Los ingeniosos visuales y la dirección, así como un final preocupantemente ambiguo, y por ende increíblemente perturbador, demuestran que aunque esta no es una película buena, si es una muy buena película, y quizás la más horripilante fuera del terror directo. Advierto que son más de 2 horas de contenido sensible.
Amazing deep story that was told perfectly by Kubrick. And Mcdowell was also amazing.
A classic movie with a strong and meaningful message
This movie is AMAZING

This is the kind of movie everyone should see at least once, if they think they can stomach the gruesome scenes of violence and sexual assault amongst other disturbing psychological torture. This is not a pleasant film, but it is a very interesting and thought provoking one. It is barely comedic at times, but this is a deep dramatic dark thriller that is shockingly good. The concepts and theming in this movie are so powerful, along with some freakishly impressive acting. The score is also quite unnervingly haunting. Kubrick has left yet another mark on the list of conceptually dark, yet intelligent films.

''A CLOCKWORK ORANGE'' tells the story of Alex, a young man who leads a gang of friends. After he is arrested, he undergoes treatment to make him a good person. Stanley Kubrick's work becomes a movie classic when he manages to mix violence with a light and fun language, in the scene where they invade the writer's house and sing "Sing in the rain" while spacing and abusing the residents is an example. . The film, in addition to the scenes of violence and sex, addresses important themes such as social behavior and the consequence of a world that does not care about the attitudes of the subject, but about the media reception and politics.

Alex DeLarge (Malcolm McDowell) and his gang of Droogs inhabit a dystopian London of the unspecified future, preoccupied with physical assaults, rape, murder and intimidation, all under the umbrella of ‘ultra-violence.'  Faithful to the Anthony Burgess source material, Stanley Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange is a nightmare come to life.  McDowell is nothing short of fantastic in the lead role, simultaneously charming and terrifying.  It's immediately identifiable as a Kubrick film – long takes, almost imperceptibly slow zooms, and all of the other Kubrick traits evident in his work from 2001: A Space Odyssey onward.  There are moments that either don't work or are inconsistent with the style (the fast motion menage-a-trois scene, for example), but it remains a memorable landmark film.
Fun, iconic and memorable. It also has the strongest message I've seen in a movie.

I remember reading this book back in early high school in the late 1970's. Then, my friends all went to see this movie at the local art house movie theater in Newport Beach, California, not much longer after that. I decided to watch it again recently forty years later and was impressed that it held up so well. But, it is a product of its time no doubt. Malcolm McDowell's performance is still great and has a witty, devious hilarity to it at times as in his conversation with some power seeking political leader who wants to use him for political gain while fork feeding him pieces of steak.
What a fantastic movie. A young man who's a criminal life takes a turn for the worse. This is a great movie and a must watch
Magnificent! Another great work by Kubrick. It's one of the most intense stories I've ever seen in a movie. It's impeccable.
The best of kubrick this is a masterpiece
Dystopic overestimated film. 5/10
Hard to watch for a pretty specific group of people but honestly if this movie bothers you you’re either high or a snowflake.

I like and respect Stanley Kubrick, and feel that along with 2001, Dr Strangelove, Full Metal Jacket and Barry Lyndon, A Clockwork Orange is one of his best films. It is probably Kubrick's most controversial film, but it is also one of his most fascinating at the same time. It is the sort of movie that you need to see more than once though, I didn't think much of it first time I love it and appreciate it much more now for what it set out to do.

A Clockwork Orange is a shocking film I give you that, particularly with the rape and sadistic ultra-violence in the first half, and the scenes where Alex is being brainwashed do bring forth ambiguous messages. Still, like with the rest of Kubrick's work it is very well made, has a haunting soundtrack that fits wonderfully with the tone of the film(especially loved the use of the Beethoven), superb writing and direction from Kubrick and a compelling story that evokes thought afterword complete with a purposefully unrepentent ending. Also Malcolm McDowell is absolutely superb in what I consider the performance of his career.

In conclusion, very fascinating film. 10/10 Bethany Cox

Kubrick got to indulge his appetite for cutting-edge movie-making while still filming an accessible story, which is more than I can say for either the preceding "2001" or the soon-to-follow snoozefest, Barry Lyndon.

Plenty of female nudity although most of it in the wrong tone. Beautiful camera movement and angles. Stunning imagery conveyed through set design and makeup. A bit boring in terms of surround but the music is excellent. The dialogue is fine but lacking depth. The sound effects are sometimes a bit ropey. An interesting story well told. It has some fascinating political undertones. It is a full circle movie where the story makes sense from beginning to end referencing earlier encounters and making every shot important. Every aspiring director should watch this to get a sense of content and how to pack it in. A truly interesting experiment that is fascinating but not entertaining.

Bu film hakkında konuşulacak çok şey var ama kısa keseceğim. Kubrick takıntıları olan obsesif ''MANYAK'' bir yönetmen. Oyuncuları sanki hipnoz ile etki altına alıp bu kadar güzel oyunculuklar sergiletiyor ve görüntüler çekiyor. Uyarlama olsa da efsane bir senaryo, çok güzel çekimler iyi sinematografi, gayet iyi oyunculuklar ve bolca +18 sahne. Birçok derin alt metne sahip olan bu filmin yeri bende ayrıdır. Defalarca izleyeceğiniz ve her seferinde başka bir şey çıkaracağınız bir başyapıt, Belki biraz abarttım ama olsun. NOT: Kubrick oyuncularla arkadaş olup film bittikden sonra hiç konuşmazmış.

I know this film is a classic, but that doesn't mean I have to like it. Yes, it is an ingenious and thought provoking way to prod the minds of society into self-reflection, but I felt gross after watching it. This is a necessary film to watch for anyone looking to dig deeper into cinema, but I cannot imagine someone watching this casually. I know the world is a sick place, but I would hope that most people have more decency than that. Kubrick knows how to create a stir...
Great cinema. Funny dialogue once you start to understand the slang. A very entertaining spin on the age old topic of human choice.

So I have been watching classic films lately and I have to say this 1971 movie of Stanley Kubrick based from the book of the great Anthony Burgess, IS A REAL PIECE OF ART!  Undeniably a SUBSTANCE OVER STYLE kind unlike Pulp Fiction that was just short-lived and no true character development. 

In A Clockwork Orange, it did not just emphasize the psychological reality of the young transitioning to critical phases of their lives filled with impulsivity, or that they may just be mixed in the wrong influence; instead, it lead to the revelation of a misunderstood world and that the protagonist-antagonist is in fact by privileged nurture and nature, the sick monster that he is. On the other hand, I absolutely love the play of words the entire movie. The script must be such an interesting read every time they rehearse and THE ENERGY OF THE ACTORS at every scene is just magnificent! The dilemma of the movie hits social issues right on the spot. Truly a worth it film to watch and treasure. The irony at the end was just fitting. I would never forget the iconic totality of this gem. 

PS EVAN PETERS LOOKS SO MUCH LIKE HIM I CANNOT 🤯🤯🤯
one of the best film that I watched.The acters was super.The subject of the movie was olso great.So it is a great film

The classical music from The Thieving magpie overture and Symphony no 9 maybe delightful but the graphic content combined with it is overbearing to see.  Stanley Kubrick had a style with the visuals but the graphic content and mature themes destroy the film and combine it with the classical music make A Clockwork Orange distracting and impolite to see.

Uno dei film più disturbanti mai prodotti; riesce a creare un senso di disagio che muta completamente col mutare della situazione del suo protagonista.
Il Drugo passa da predatore a vittima, nel mezzo ad infinite scene e citazioni che diventeranno cult, impone ed obbliga lo spettatore ad odiarlo prima e a provare compassione in seguito per terminare con l'unico momento di quiete, proprio nei momenti finali.
Il tutto incorniciato da una colonna sonora quanto mai protagonista del film oltre che di altissima qualità ed emotività.
Una delle opere di maggior successo di Kubrick; iconica ed unica.
One of the most overrated movies of all time.  It is a disturbing for a movie that was released in 1971 and that is what made it popular.

While this is a must see-especially today I am not sure the word like is appropriate for this one.  It is so deeply disturbing and though provoking.  It does hold up after 50 years.  Malcom MacDowell's performance is brilliant.   About half way through the film the essential question is asked "if a man is forced to be good and this is not his choice; then is he really good?  Is he really a man?"  What is the essence of goodness, and what is free will?   The film is supposed to be closely based on the acclaimed novel; however, I have not read it.  Kubrick's filmmaking is stunning, unique, brutal, and violent.   The images are disturbing.   This looks at the conflict over the views on the nature of man, and that view impacts the response to crime and violence.   50 years later I feel the questions are the same, and we are no closer to answers.   Law and order people may argue it doesn't matter whether good behavior is the result of free will; it is the result we seek.  The humanist may not be so happy with that approach regardless of positive outcome.  Aside from Other Kubrick films few movies evoke such conversations and thoughts.  The visuals are cinematically original and visually, truly unique to Kubrick.
Best movie of history, with excelent connections, and an excelent story

This movie is one of Kubrick's best work. At first, I thought that I may not like this movie but no, I loved it. This is such a different kind of crime drama which is almost impossible to remake. The performances by the actors and the direction, both were great. Movie had so many elements such as satire, political, crime, drama, dark humour etc and everything fitted perfectly. Overall, a great watch and would recommend this as it is a different experience.

Amazing use of Beethoven, amazing cinematography, amazing acting, amazing score, and amazing plot. What more could you need from a film? I consider A Clockwork Orange an artistic masterpiece. Thank you Stanley Kubrick.
